newsitem.title: UK: E.Europe up in debt market, Latam awaits US numbers.
newsitem.headline: E.Europe up in debt market, Latam awaits US numbers.

text.p: Russia and Poland debt prices were firmer on Friday but Latin American paper was steady ahead of U.S. durable good figures for July, traders said.
"The market is pretty quiet. The only action is in non-Latin paper. There is good buying in Poland and Russia," said one.
But, he added, Latin American Bradys were quiet ahead of US durable good figures for July, expected at 1230 GMT, with forecasts predicting 0.3 percent growth from June.
"Investors are waiting to see what effect the figure will have on US treasuries before taking positions," he added.
Polish paper was buoyed on Friday by unconfirmed talk that certain paper had received an investment grade from the U.S. National Association of Insurance Commissioners (NAIC).
"If it has received an NAIC rating, the move is significant because it would allow U.S. insurers to invest in those Polish debt instruments and would broaden the investor base," said one analyst.
In London, Poland Pars were trading at 52.365/52.875 while Poland Discs were trading at 95.000/95.375.
The yields, said traders, were on Friday at their lowest level since issuance but could narrow further.
Russian paper also made headway as renewed jitters over President Boris Yeltsin's health were quelled by his television apperance and return to the Kremlin on Thursday.
Analysts said cooling tension in Chechnya had also helped.
Peter West, economic adviser at West Merchant Bank, said now Yeltsin is back in the Kremlin and the crisis over Chechnya had been diffused, political concern had waned.
"Investors have Russia in their sights. If all goes according to plan, there is plenty more room the upside," said West.
